Docs.summary: Provides design-time support in a visual designer for the Web server control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus> control renders a button that automatically checks the authentication status of the user and displays the appropriate login or logout option.
In a visual designer, when you switch from Source to Design view, the markup source code that describes the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus> control is parsed and a design-time version of the control is created on the design surface. When you switch back to Source view, the design-time control is persisted to the markup source code and edited into the markup for the Web page. The LoginStatusDesigner class provides design-time support for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus> control.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.WebControls.LoginStatusDesigner.ActionLists%2A> property returns a <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.DesignerActionListCollection> object, which typically contains an object that is derived from the <xref:System.ComponentModel.Design.DesignerActionList> class for each level in the inheritance tree of the designer. The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.WebControls.LoginStatusDesigner.UsePreviewControl%2A> property always returns `true`, indicating that the designer creates a temporary copy of the associated <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus> to generate the design-time markup, since the user authentication status is not available at design time.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.WebControls.LoginStatusDesigner.GetDesignTimeHtml%2A> method returns the markup that is used to render the associated <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus> at design time. The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.WebControls.LoginStatusDesigner.Initialize%2A> method prepares the designer to view, edit, and design the associated <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus>.
## Examples The following code example shows how to extend the LoginStatusDesigner class to change the appearance of controls that are derived from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus> control at design time.
The example derives the `MyLoginStatus` control from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus>. The `MyLoginStatus` is a copy of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus> control. The example also derives the `MyLoginStatusDesigner` class from LoginStatusDesigner, and then applies a <xref:System.ComponentModel.DesignerAttribute> attribute for the `MyLoginStatusDesigner` on the `MyLoginStatus` control.
The `MyLoginStatusDesigner` overrides the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.WebControls.LoginStatusDesigner.GetDesignTimeHtml%2A> method to draw a blue, dashed border around the control to make it more visible, if the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebControl.BorderStyle%2A> property of the `MyLoginStatus` is the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.BorderStyle> or <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.BorderStyle> value.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LogoutText%2A> or <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LoginText%2A> property (depending on whether the user is logged in), is `null`, an empty string (""), or a single space (" "), the GetDesignTimeHtml method sets the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LogoutText%2A> or <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LoginText%2A> property, as appropriate, to the <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.ID%2A> property, enclosed in brackets ("[ ]"). Then, regardless of the setting of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LoginText%2A> or <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus.LogoutText%2A>, the GetDesignTimeHtml method calls the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.WebControls.CompositeControlDesigner.GetDesignTimeHtml%2A> base method to generate the markup for the design-time rendering of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus> control.
## Examples The following code example shows how to override the GetDesignTimeHtml method in a class that is inherited from the <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.WebControls.LoginStatusDesigner> class to change the appearance of a control that is derived from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus> class at design time. The example draws a blue, dashed border around the control to make its extent more visible, if the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebControl.BorderStyle%2A> property of the control is the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.BorderStyle> or <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.BorderStyle> value.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The visual designer calls the Initialize method when it is ready to use the designer to render the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus> control. The Initialize and its base methods configure properties and set up events that are necessary for the operation of the designer.
The `component` parameter is the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus> control that is associated with this designer or a copy of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus> control.

Docs.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the designer should use a temporary copy rather than the actual control that is associated with the designer to generate the design-time markup.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Because the UsePreviewControl property is always `true`, the designer <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.ViewControl%2A> property returns a copy of the associated <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus> control to generate the design-time markup. The <xref:System.Web.UI.Design.ControlDesigner.ViewControl%2A> property creates the copy by persisting the actual <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus> control, then parsing the persisted control string. The copied control does not affect any persistence for the actual <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus>.
If the UsePreviewControl property has been overridden to return `false`, the designer will use the associated <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.LoginStatus> itself to generate the design-time markup, and design-time changes to the control will persist to the page markup source.
